description.text:
Great optical illusion. This concave sculpture of Buddha appears 3D when you look at it straight on and then as you move, his head appears to follow you... tilting up, down, left and right in the direction you move. You can even simulate this just by rotating the model with Thingiview.

The original printed with a large hole in the bottom for me because the base is so thin, so I increased the thickness of the base and now it prints without issue.

You could use your imagination and adopt these to other environments as well, such as a bubbling pool of magma or a wizards pool for raising water monsters or a connection to the depths of some deeper or more chaotic world.
I have also provided my 4x3 base that works with openlock and is not available anywhere else that I am aware of.

print_settings.Notes:: If the friction in the dove-tail joints is not enough, increase the extrusion multiplier (to ca. 105%). If the dove-tail joints are too tight, try sanding them off a little to get the right fit.

title: Surround Print Cooler - 50x50 radial fan (for E3D type hotends)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
----------------------- 50 x 50 mm RADIAL FAN version -----------------------

This "Remix" of my previous print coolers integrates some useful feedback I received from people who printed and used the old versions. Although these worked fine for me, I have to admit they were designed quite tight and some people had problems with the cooler duct touching the nozzle or they had trouble getting the BLTouch in.

THANKS to everyone who provided feedback on the design!

Following points are updated / changed:

  • The distance between the cooling duct and the heating block is now large enough to avoid touching in any situation. This also leaves more space for the heater cables.
  • The section diameter of the cooling duct is increased to minimize pressure loss
  • The mounting requires only screws for the fans. The two components (print cooler and radiator cooler) are now held together exclusively by dove-tail friction joints
  • Cleaner and improved overall geometry
  • Added double fan version for those who need more cooling power

The radius of the cooling pipe leaves enoguh space between the 3D printed part and the heating block. However, I recommend that you insulate your heating block with fireproof insulation (you can find it in any 3D printer store or online) for 3 reasons:

  • To avoid the pipe getting heat deformations
  • To avoid cooling down the hotend and destabilizing the temperature PID controller
  • To avoid heating up the cooling air

I hope that you will like and successfully use this cooler! Please provide feedback for potential improvements.

Acknowledgement:

  • Benjamin Grosjean / GrabCAD - 3D model of the fans (https://grabcad.com/library/fan-40-x-40-mm-1)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15-0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

It will take ca. 20g filament.

If the friction in the dove-tail joints is not enough, increase the extrusion multiplier (to ca. 105%). If the dove-tail joints are too tight, try sanding them off a little to get the right fit.

The aluminium radiator has a diameter that can vary between 22 and 22.5 mm. I designed the radiator fan duct for 22mm, so for some of you, this might be too tight and lead to breaking the clips during mounting.

If the radiator fan duct clips are too tight, try heating them up a little before mounting, to avoid breaking them. Alternatively, you can use a rotary tool to grind them off until they fit.

1. Import one of the “Print_Cooler” .STP files (without holes) in your prefered CAD software.

  2. Estimate the center (O) of the main cooling duct torus.

  3. Move this point vertically at a certain distance H (default: 7mm) from the nozzle. This will be the point where the air jets will be aiming. Do not place it to close to the nozzle, else you risk cooling down and clogging the nozzle.

  4. In “front” or “right” view, draw a line from “O” to a point iside the cooling duct.

  5. Multiply this line in a circular pattern (16-30 elements should be fine).

  6. Adjust the lines in the area of the BLTouch bulge.

  7. Use the created lines as axes for pipes with D = 1.6-3 mm.

  8. Subtract those pipes from the imported “Print_Cooler” .STP geometry.

  9. Delete the pipes and lines to reveal the customized model.

The cooling assembly has 2 parts:

  1. Print cooler for 50x50 radial fans (I included a version with no holes too, if you want to change the hole pattern and orientation)
  2. Radiator fan holder, or radiator cooler for 30x30 axial fans

I designed them as two separate parts to be easier to mount and print without supports.

For the mounting, you will only need 3 or 4 M3 screws (for the fans). The length of those will depend on the depth of your fan, but generally, M3x15 - M3x25mm should work.

Assembly order:

  1. insulate your heating block
  2. clip in the radiator fan holder
  3. slide the 50 x 50 mm radial fans over the slots on the print cooler (sand it to fit if it's too tight)
  4. slide the assembly into the dove-tail joints (if needed) and fix it to the radiator cooler with M3 screws (or similar)
  5. mount the 30 x30 mm axial fan to the radiator cooler with M3 screws (or similar)
  6. adjust your PID (if necessary)
  7. enjoy your improved cooling

comments.text: Really awesome design, but could you also post a version without a bulge for the BLtouch if you ever get around to remaking that thing? I tried to tweak it a bit in Fusion 360 but it's kind of hard with just the step file.
comments.author: desolatus

comments.text:
Hi,
i really like your design, but i would recommend , you should add a small groove at the top, so that it is impossible , that the cooler falls down the radiator of the e3d.
second thing, a version for 40mm Fan at the radiator would be perfect, because the 30mm (even the newer one of e3d) is very loud. to have it more silent, the smallest Noctua Fan NF A4x10 FLX, that is also used on prusa i3 mk3 , is necessary.
looking forward to a nice update on that....
comments.author: giftyakapatch

comments.text:

comments.text:
HI megablue,
Thanks for your feedback. It is true that the old design was a little louder. However, there was also for the old design a version with bigger holes. Did you try the new one? Both holes and pipe are larger, so this design should be quieter. Regarding the high pitch whistle, I would say it is more related to the quality of the holes. I had similar sounds comming out when the holes where not perfectly round (too high printing temperature lead to a "squeezed" shape). Solved it by drilling the holes perfectly round. I hope this helps.

title: TEVO Little Monster Belt Tensioning Tool

description.text:
A completely 3D printed belt tensioning tool for the TEVO Little Monster. Uses an eccentric cam to provide 0 to 5 mm push action on the pulley plate to tighten the belt.

With this you can tension belts much tighter and more consistently than trying to do it by hand:

  • holds the pulley plate in place when screws are loosened and during tensioning
  • provides scale of plate offset for better repeatability

I tensioned my belts by 3 mm from rest, no tension position. I find that at the maximum 5 mm setting the belts feel too tight.

The plunger contacts a 10mm segment of the cam to distribute the force on the plunger and the cam. This makes the plunger tilt slightly as the cam is rotated and pushes on one side causing the pulley plate to be slightly off-horizontal.

Depending on how tight you want your belts, you will probably need the wrench to make turning the knob easier.

Printer:

TEVO Little Monster

Resolution:

varies by part

Infill:

varies by part

Notes:

I printed mine with PLA.

The back of the enclosure comes in two files BeltTensioningTool_Back.stl which contains the plunger that pushes on the plate already in place, offset by 0.3 mm from the main body. The BeltTensioningTool_Back_Only.stl is only the back of the enclosure and you will need to print the BeltTensioningTool_Plunger.stl separately.

I found it easier to remove the plunger with a few knocks with a small hammer on a 1/8" metal flat scrap than to try and wiggle the supports from that space. If you have no issues getting supports out of the slot for the plunger than you can print the two parts separately.

I also printed the back of the enclosure at 70% infill, which is overkill for the enclosure but I was concerned it would be needed by the plunger since it does all the pushing. However, you can print the enclosure and plunger at 40% infill and then throw out the plunger and print one at 70%. It will still be faster than printing the back and plunger at 70% infill.

NOTE: The plunger goes into the slot from the pulley compartment.

Print settings

Case Back

NOTE You only need to print one of the BeltTensioningTool_Back.stl or BeltTensioningTool_Back_Only.stl

  • 0.25 mm layer height
  • 40% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom and 3 perimeter layers
  • support required
  • no raft
Case Front
  • 0.25 mm layer height
  • 40% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom and 3 perimeter layers
  • NOTE: Top 0.75mm is the scale lettering and 0.5 mm gradations. If you want you can change the filament color at this point to have the scale stand out from the case.
  • no support
  • no raft
Cam
  • 0.25 mm layer height
  • 70% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom and 3 perimeter layers
  • support required
  • no raft
Wrench
  • 0.25 mm layer height
  • 70% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom and 3 perimeter layers
  • no support
  • no raft
V-Groove Fasteners (6x)
  • 0.2 mm layer height
  • 70% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom and 3 perimeter layers
  • no support
  • raft required
Plunger
  • 0.2 mm layer height
  • 70% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom and 3 perimeter layers
  • no support
  • no raft

Knock the plunger from the slot in the back of the case (if you printed the version with the plunger in place)

You may need to clean up the inside surfaces of the case back with some sand paper to reduce the friction between the cam and the case.

You should also make the cam surface and plunger end that contacts with it smooth for the the same reason. A little dry graphite lubricant would probably help.

Assembling the Tool

Place the plunger into its slot in the case back shell. Note the plunger has a short limit skirt that should be up and face the back of the case as you slide it into the slot.

Push the plunger down as far as it will go and then insert the cam and place the front case cover over the whole thing.

The front and back have two small holes you can use to screw the two parts together. The force during tensioning is handled by the v-groove fasteners. These screws only serve to keep the two halves together so any screws can be used for the purpose.

Work-in the V-Groove Fasteners

Prepare the v-groove fasteners by removing them from the raft and attaching the mini holding plate to the column.

The fasteners are inserted with the top arms in the vertical position and fastened by turning them 90 degrees into a horizontal position.

You may need to use pliers to turn them for the first time. After that they can be fastened by hand.

Using The Tensioner

1. Turn the knob to the 0 setting and place the tensioner over the pulley plate on the column.

2. The pulley plate bolts should only be loosened after you have the tensioner over it to keep the plate in place.

3. Loosen the two bolts holding the pulley plate.

4. Hold the tensioner against the pulley plate with very little force. You want to have plunger and pulley plate contact but add only minimal tension to the belts.

5. Fasten the tensioner to the column by turning the six v-groove fasteners from their 90 degree position. The PLA fastners have less give and you may only need to turn them 30-45 degrees off vertical for them to lock.

6. Turn the knob in any direction from 0 to tighten the belts. Test to see at what setting you find the tension sufficient.

7. Tighten the two pulley plate bolts to fasten the plate in its position.

8. Turn the tensioner knob to 0.

9. Check if the belt tension held. If not then one of the nuts turned and did not catch inside the v-groove. Loosen both bolts and repeat step 5.

10. Turn the v-groove fasteners to their vertical, unlocked positions and remove the tensioner from the column.

11. Repeat for the other two belts.

author: Grenwall

description.text:
Pazaak, an ancient game dating back to Old Republic times, was a popular card game in which the goal was to reach 20 without going over, or at least come closer to it than the opponent. The player with the nearest sum to the number 20 won the round, and the player who won three rounds won the match. If in one round the scores of the two players were equal, the round was not counted at all.

Very fun, very competitive. Great for parties, and passing time.
Updated versions to follow.

http://starwars.wikia.com/wiki/Pazaak/Legends

title: Fan Duct for Raise3D N2 Dual Extruder Used As Single Extruder

description.text:
I have a dual-extruder N2, and have little interest in using the second extruder (I wish I had bought a single-extruder).
This is an improved right-side fan duct for much better part cooling when only the left extruder is to be used.
It directs All of the air from the right-side OEM 35mm fan onto the part, instead of wasting 3/4 of the airflow on cooling an unused heater. By moving one connector on the printhead, you can also program the fan speed in your slicer for perfect cooling.
Note that it requires removal of the right nozzle and that clearances are tight. I moved the washers from outside the fan, to the left, inside the duct, to clear the cooling fins.

Printer:

Raise3D N2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed it in PolyPC polycarbonate in .1mm layers, with glass/gluestick bed at 110 and extruder at 264.

I hacked this from the Raise3D stls, using Tinkercad.
While I was at it, I scaled a matching left-side fan-duct to the same height as the final injection-molded piece used by Raise3D - about 3mm taller than the Kickstarter version.
Both ducts are included here.

author: Blue5280

title: Wemos D1 Mini ESP8266 LED & Level Shifter Shield Enclosure & Lid

description.text:
Case for Wemos D1 Mini ESP8266 LED & Level Shifter Shield

This is a case for the Wemos D1 Mini ESP8266 LED & Level Shifter Shield, which makes it easy to control addressable RGB LEDs such as WS2811, WS2812 (Adafruit NeoPixels), SK6812, APA102 (Adafruit DotStars), and SK9822. The Wemos D1 Mini is an excellent mini Wi-Fi development board based on the ESP8266. I've used it extensively in development of addressable RGB LED art projects such as my 6.5ft Rainbow Tree.

The shield includes a 74HCT245 level shifter, which is the most well-regarded high speed level shifter I've found. This shifts the 3.3V logic level of the ESP8266 to the 5V expected by addressable RGB LEDs. These projects often work fine without a level shifter, until they don't.

Four digital output pins (D5 - D8) are run through the level shifter. These pins support parallel output by the fantastic FastLED library.

The shield also includes places for data line resistors and a large 1000uF capacitor as recommended when driving LEDs, especially when powering the microcontroller from the same power supply as a large number of LEDs. Duplicate breakouts are included for each of the Wemos D1 mini pins. The shield also includes a spot for easily adding an IR receiver.

description.text:
Once upon a time, I tried to print with flexible filaments. Alas, despite all efforts the filament would wrap itself around the gears at any opportunity.

So here is a widget that now has me printing all manner of squidgy, bendable objects. Hooray!

Notes
You probably want to print with supports enabled as there is a hole in the base for the heater stalk thingy to thread into.
My printer can give edges which are quite bumpy, but a quick finish in the filament hole with a 2mm drill bit smoothed the edges right out and the filament runs very freely.

If you need to tweak the design for your printer, let me know and I'll share the Fusion 30 files with you.

Another fan duct for the X-one. This cools it from two sides.

I tried to keep the air path from making sharp turns, so it is stupid big and curvy.

description.text:
I have a plan to do a dual extruder CR-10 and I love the heavy duty mount that graham did so I took it and remixed it to work with the chimera dual hotend I had to cover up the 3rd mounting screw hole but you can always drill out if you need that screw although with the 2 lower screws and the lip going over the plate I think it will be very solid I haven't printed it out but this should work for the original e3d v6 I might have to make the feed holes bigger for the clones if you want to do a dual extruder set up on your CR-10 I'll leave a parts list to what I got coming in the mail (ordered from china going to take forever)

4 a nema 17 motor (I got 2 incase I needed to do a dual lead screw)

6 bowden tube and lots of it (I plan to put both motors on the top bar so I bought 2 600mm tubes)
7 motor mounts (I'm printing mine out)

author: propmaker

title: Battery Adapter Bracket for Shorai LFX36-BS12

description.text:
This bracket should allow any standard auto battery mount to be adapted to hold a Shorai LFX36-BS12 lithium battery. It should fit on other batteries that have the same dimensions but I have only tested it on an LFX36-BS12. It contains three pieces that interlock and are held tightly together once the mount is bolted down.

A couple notes:
-Don't use PLA or other low-temp plastics, they will not hold up to engine bay heat
-Use a large washer on the nuts to spread the load out on the crossbar piece
-The shorai battery is shorter than standard size batteries, you might have to cut threads farther down the studs to be able to tighten the bracket all the way.
-Shorai does not support their batteries for automotive use, you may or may not get warranty if your battery dies!
-Use these parts at your own risk, I'm not responsible for any accidents, mechanical problems, etc.

title: Gears that are sized for 1" pegboard

description.text:
In working on another project I realized that there were not gears on thingiverse to date that were sized for the standard 1" pegboard. This was really frustrating, until I tried to create my own and I realized why this was so darn difficult once I dug into it. But here they are, a set of gears that are sized to work on a pegboard. Not everything will fit perfectly with one another but there are lots of combinations that will work. The number indicates how many teeth are on the gear, which in turn determine how big it is.

There are two peg types. If your pegboard is already in a raised surface you can use the top down pegs to simply drop down through the gear and hole.

The upright version is basically a stand that will support the pegboard from underneath. Use these to give you clearance. You can either use these for all of your gears or just set them up in the corners and in the middle to make it stable then use the drop downs everywhere else.

Which gears work These combinations will ensure that the center of your gear sits directly over a hole. These combinations are moving left, right, up, and down on the pegboard, not diagonally, although some are pretty close diagonally and other combinations may work that I haven't tested when it comes to diagonals.
12 and 17
12 and 46
12 and 76
17 and 100
17 and 40 How to make more gears. I created the gears themselves in a combination of Inkscape and Tinkercad. If you'd like to make gears of different sizes but that will work with these gears you'll want to start in Inkscape(free program) Go to Extentions>Render>Gear>Gear Then use these settings:
Number of teeth: You pick, the bigger the number the bigger the gear
Circular Pitch: 0.2
Pressure Angle 20.0
Diameter of center hole: 0.0
Units: Inches
Then hit apply. This will create a gear with the number of teeth you designated. Next fill in the gear. Make sure your new gear is selected
Object>Fill and Stroke
This should open the fill and stroke window, click on the solidly filled square to fill your object. Now save it. Next head to Tinkercad, create a new tinker, and hit import.
Now you will likely get a warning that it is too big to import. This next step is VERY important to make sure the gears will work with mine. You need to scale it to 30. That should get rid of the warning and you can import your new object. To make a hole in the center add a cylinder that is .3 inches x .3 inches. Center the two objects using the alignment tool. Make the cylinder a hole and combine the two. Experiment with other shapes to make fun holes elsewhere in your design for flair.

author: EricKiatko

title: Flash insulated air mattress drying adapter

description.text:
This adapter connects the inflation port of a REI Flash backpacking insulated air mattress to a small squirrel-cage blower to accelerate drying the inside of the sleeping pad.

If you inflate the Flash on the trail using your mouth/lungs, you'll be blowing very moist air into it. Once home, it's difficult to dry out the inside. REI advise laying the mattress flat and opening both ports until it dries, but I find I can still see moisture droplets inside for many days that way. Shine a flashlight from the backside to see the droplets.

Using this adapter connected to the inflation port, and leaving the deflation port open I can dry a mattress out approximately overnight. The blower used generates very low pressure, so it's not going to damage the pad seams by overinflation. (The pad does not, and IMO should not, fully inflate while being dried.)

The 2017 Flash has a different design (squarer) and different color (red), but should still fit. It is listed as using the same pump accessories.

The fan needed is here:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00MJU6JR2

The version of the Flash which I have looks like this:
http://www.backpackgeartest.org/reviews/Sleep%20Gear/Pads%20and%20Air%20Mattresses/REI%20Flash%20Insulated%20Air%20Sleeping%20Pad/Test%20Report%20by%20Brian%20Hartman/

This fan happens to have a small ridge on top. My adapter design latches onto that ridge to stay put. It also latches into the pad's inflation port. I power the fan with a small 12v supply. In use the blower draws less than 100mA.

I printed this successfully using PLA, 0.2mm layers, 0.4mm nozzle size and it has a good snap fit on both the pad port and the fan.

comments.text: This is brilliant. I wish my pad had two ports to make this an option.
comments.author: Tinfoil_Haberdashery

author: jdcthingiverse

description.text: This is version 3 and the final version of my Pinning tray. For those of you in to lock sport, you know how valuable a pinning tray can be. As seen on youtube, this is my latest version.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

I printed an X-Actmundo a few months ago and have used it a lot.

It's so useful that it was swiped from my workbench by another avid maker in this house for sculpting! When I couldn't find it I downloaded the stl to print another, but it's juuuust large enough to be difficult to fit in the printable area of my delta printer, so I wanted to make a slightly smaller version. These handles are designed from scratch, but are a re-creation of the original.

Massive props to CDugD for the clever design to hold the blade in place! I stole (ahem, I mean "re-used") that geometry, and it works brilliantly.

Some small differences from the original:

  • Slightly shorter to fit smaller print beds
  • Greater front angle to expose more blade
  • Sharper curve behind blade so you can grasp closer
  • Slightly thinner handle end, to be more pencil sized
  • Chamferd handle edges for a smoother grip

Additionally there is a utility knife version, with a large grip that you can pull on firmly. Great for cutting cardboard or cloth.

These need an M3x8mm screw and an M3 nut to hold the blade in place, same as the original.

These designs are publicly available, you're welcome to go completely mad with them:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/5ab9c164b8de294653e560a6/w/4626239fce5bc14de377fbc4/e/b2a32978dcbe09e86022f8f6

title: Half inch Pipe Clamp M5 V2

I needed some element clamps for an antenna I was building. Justin G0KSC supplies Stauff branded pipe clamps with his InnovAntenna commercially produced antennas however I've decided to build one of his designs from his website at http://www.g0ksc.co.uk/ and needed some pipe clamps so I decided to print my own to similar dimensions as the Stauff clamps. I used M5 bolts as that's what I had.

This is a second version. I have omitted the recesses for the bolt heads as in some prints this seemed to introduce a weak point and one snapped on me so I decided to reprint them without the recess.

description.text:
Since I wasn't able to find a proper case for the T3 LCR-meter I decided to design my own version, with focus on:

title: XYZ DaVinci mini W - Fan duct V.4

description.text:

author: caee

title: NES Mini Clone Raspberry Pi Conversion Useful Parts

description.text:
I've recently converted one of the Chinese mini NES clones so that it now has a Raspberry Pi 3 running Retropie.

These are a few of the parts that I designed and printed to make things a little easier and neater.
They consist of:
A) A mounting bracket that ensures that the micro USB and HDMI ports on the Pi 3 line up as close as possible to the existing holes on the back of the clone case. UPDATED - Pi Mount V2 uploaded which has more material surrounding the screw holes.

B) A mounting bracket for locating 2 momentary push button switches so that the reset and on/off buttons on the clone case are fully functional.

For info on how to wire the switches and install the necessary script take a look at ElTacoLoco's excellent Thing. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2011955

C) A plate that can be used to mount 2 x USB sockets so that you can use USB controllers instead of the 9 pin connectors that these clones come supplied with. You will need to buy 2 x 90 degree USB extension cables for this purpose.

Hope these make modding the clone case a bit easier for you all.

description.text: Drain

This spout does a good job of sealing for clean transfer from messy gallon cans, to manageable quart cans. I've found that if you get a few drops, to retighten with rag and it should make a good seal.

title: Guitar Pedal Board - Printable on the MP Select Mini (120x120x120)

description.text:
Works best with mini pedals but also works with some standard-sized pedals.

See the images for guidance on how all parts fit together. For my setup I printed 3 X pedalboard_section, 4 X x_brace, 4 X x_brace_end, 2 X pedalboard_end_slanted

Print all parts first and perform a fit test before you start gluing any of them!

(I used Krazy glue, it works well so far)

pedalboard_end_slanted is a bit wider than the protruding ends of x_brace_end should be if the x_brace parts are centered between pedalboard_section parts, this allows some leeway without having x_brace_end parts protrude too much past the end parts, but a fit test is recommended for best results.

x_brace_end may be a tight fit into the pegholes of pedalboard_end_slanted. I resolved this by shaving the corners of the ends to be inserted slightly with an xacto knife - you can also try rescaling the part (without uniform scaling) and making the X or Z axis ~5% smaller

So I noticed that no matter what I designed, the holes were always too small and the post were too big. Since the holes and pegs are really not round but are approximations made by straight lines, it was understandable, but how much to compensate? I decided to see by how much and designed a fixture so that when I need a particular size, I can just measure what I came up with so that I can get a perfect fit every time.
Except for the smaller sizes, turns out that they were a constant offset. The 0.36" dia hole fit the 0.30" dia peg, the 0.30"dia hole fit on the 0.24" dia peg, etc., so if I offset the test pieces by 0.06" the holes and pegs all fit. Now I know if I want to have my 0.25" rod, I have to design it with a 0.31" hole. The peg will end up 0.24" dia and the hole will end up 0.26" dia and a perfect fit. The holes and posts are 0.100" to 0.36" dia in 0.20" increments. I've included Inventor files so you can vary the sizes to suit.
Print these in whatever resolution you are interested in. If they fit together by just offsetting, then the difference is constant. If not then it varies depending on hole size.

title: DreMill 3D printer to mill adapter with adjustable run out
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: This is so I can add a Dremel 3000 to my printer to do some milling and engraving. The three bolts up top are to adjust run-out at the bit end. Take off the nose nut and thread a Dremel into the print after you have added the bolts, there are threads built in. Also has a vent/finger hole for locking it to change bits. Adjust the bolts to true up the bit. This is a work in progress. I am busy as a whore at a Viagra convention so I haven't gotten much further than this. The latest file has recesses for jam nuts not seen here on the prototype. Pardon the crappy print, I shifted a layer but recovered and I was so close to the finish just I tripled the print speed and just let er buck. Fits a fan too. Also fits my fan adapter I published earlier. Mounting bolts will fit my machine, not sure about you. Designed to mount on a flat plate and has a lip at back to help line it up.

Monkey Shit Fight

print_settings.Notes:: Should print on any printer

description.text:
These are the files for my custom insert for CMONs board game Massive Darkness. It converts the bottom of the main box into a holder for ALL cards, tokens, class sheets, base game tile set, dice, 3D chests and pillars.

If like me you want to keep the plastic storage for the minatures but felt like the core box organization was lacking (and non sleeve friendly) this is the insert for you.

Holds everything card token class sheet wise from the base game, lightbringer ks pack as well as all other boxed expansions.

All files included. Print...
4x Small Deck Holder w Joiner.
4x Small Deck Holder
7x Large Deck Holder / Large Deck Holder w Joiner (7 in total - any mixture of these. I went with 4 joiners, 3 without)
1x of everything else.

And you're done!

For assembly just look at my uploaded picture.

For those of you that would like the measurements I used to make this... It's all listed below.

Box

31.5 x 31.5 x 12.5

Brown Box

31 x 31 x 7.5

Tiles

25 x 25 x 2.2 (9 tiles)

Class Sheets

20.6 x 13.6 x 2.6 (All sheets of all expansions)

Tokens

Depth of tokens factor in TOTAL Depth of all tokens.

Bridge Tokens - 8.7 x 8.7 x .5 (2 pieces)
Lair/Artifact/Starting Player Tokens - 5.5cm Diameter x 2.2 (7 pieces)
Exit Token - 5.4 x 3 x 0.3 (1 pieces)
Start Token - 3.6 Diameter x 0.3 (1 pieces)
Door Tokens - 2.6 x 2.6 x 3.4 (15 pieces)
Five Heart Tokens - 2.6 Diameter x 2.3 (10 pieces)
Single Heart Tokens - 2.2 Diameter x 5 (22 pieces)
Level Tokens - 3.1 Diameter x 2.4 (10 pieces)
Pillar Tokens - 2.9 x 2.9 x 1.6 (6 pieces)
Sup Chest Tokens - 2.6 x 2.6 x 1 (4 pieces)
Chest Tokens - 2.6 x 2.6 x 2.5 (10 pieces)

Cards

6.6 x 9.2 x 1.5 (sleeved per 20)
4.5 x 6.8 x 1.5 (guess for sleeved per 20 - I've no sleeves that fit)

title: Model 8 iPhone 6/7/8 Flip Case With Recessed Hinges

description.text:
A redesign of my old single hinge flip case. This newer version features; a stronger hinge, screen cut out, an open slot for the headphone jack, and pins to hold down the lid of the case.

What makes this case better than previous iterations?

The hinges aren't as weak and cumbersome, the hinges are now recessed inside the dimensions of the body and increases the length of the case by couple of millimeters. I've included 2 pins that insert at the bottom of the case as an option to hold the phone in the case if necessary.

My flip case looks more professional, and is more durable in this iteration.

Hello everyone, I'm updating this summary to let everyone know that this case is will work on the iPhone 6, iPhone 6s, iPhone 7, and iPhone 8. I'm also working on a case for the iPhone 5, iPhone 5s, and iPhone SE, seeing as how replacement parts for the older series of iPhones are getting more expensive, I feel that a free case will benefit everyone. I will also start making cases for the iPhone X and android devices.

PowerSpec

Printer:

PowerSpec 3D Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

0.2 mm to 0.25 mm

Infill:

0% to 100%

Notes:

Infill percentage is up to your discretion.
Number of shells ranges from zero to three.
The more shells the higher chance there is of the hinges fusing

cleaning up the case

using something like a painters pallet knife, use the blade to separate lid from the body. I urge caution as it's very easy to damage the hinges. Remove any support material from between the hinges and body and from all gaps. Next check to make sure all supports are removed. Lastly use a pallet knife to gently torque the hinges open carefully and with constant force as not to break the hinges.

description.text:
Got tired of the hair brushes taking up room on the sink so I designed this to hold them on the side. It takes 2 screws, one on the bottom on the inside. The top tab will break if you don't use the bottom screw if someone bends it accidentally. Worked out good. The brushes are a snug fit. Scale it for bigger brushes.  
I added another one to hold a brush that's 2.25" dia. Scaling made the rest of ot grow too much.

Prints without support standing up. Use two #8 flat head wood screws for mounting. Use needle nose pliers to hold the screw in the bottom hole while you start it and use the hole in the side of the bottom for the screwdriver. Hole centers are 5 in. apart.

title: CATAN center tiles and pips (by Glowforge)

description.text:
The center tiles have straight edge or jigsaw options (straight is recommended) and measure 3 3/4" x 4" each. This digital file includes:

-6 grain tiles (wheat).
-6 lumber tiles (tree).
-6 wool tiles (sheep)
-5 ore tiles (stone)
-5 brick tiles
-2 desert tiles
-Center pips
-30 Felt cutouts for center tiles and pips

These tiles interlock with the waves I made and are enough for the base 2-4 player game + 4-6 player expansion. https://www.etsy.com/listing/540076560/catan-wave-borders?ref=listing-shop-header-0

Catan set made by Glowforge and is filed under the Creative Commons Attribution. It cannot replace the official Catan game produced by Mayfair, and a copy of said game will need to be purchased in order to have all pieces required for gameplay.

Original Glowforge files: https://glowforge.com/laser-cut-catan-board
Official Mayfair Catan board game: http://www.catan.com/

This version you are downloading here was compiled by Carlotta4th and has minor changes from the Glowforge files, as follows:

-Pieces added to expand the set from 2-4 players to 4-6 players
-Center circles given a larger lip
-Sheep tile inverted so outside etch is lighter
-Various cleanup, some lines thickened others reduced, etc.
-Tile sizes scaled down slightly
-Cut lines recreated and are now .001 thickness

If you are unsure of how many tiles you will need or would like general tutorials here is a helpful link: https://imgur.com/a/e1dZm

My digital files are mix-and-match to make your own custom set. All purchaseable digital files are available in my etsy shop, and any free files (including the default center tiles) are available through thingiverse here.

Etsy: https://www.etsy.com/shop/EttuArtem
Thingiverse: https://www.thingiverse.com/Carlotta4th/designs

comments.text: I cut the files from glowforge using a full spectrum hobby laser. One issue I ran into, is that the teeth don't always lock together easily. There is a bit of an accuracy/uniformity issue. Did you change anything with the teeth in your files that may resolve this issue?
comments.author: yashrg

comments.text: When lasercutting small pieces sometimes wood can expand or warp a bit, and this may be what you're running into. That's actually why I suggest people use the hexagon option instead of the jigsaw one--the jigsaw ones look lovely, but it's harder to get the wood to act appropriately. The hexagon pieces are easier to set up and if the wood warps a bit during cutting it won't matter.

title: Creality CR-10 Mini IR Sensor Mount

description.text:
Simple mount for the mini ir z probe sensor board found here to be used with Auto Bed Leveling. Requires flashing the firmware.

Uses stock screw hole on left side after removing the fan housing and allows for height adjustment to get to just the right spot.

Connect VCC to 5V, GND to Z end stop ground pin and OUT to the other Z end stop pin. Enable FIX_MOUNTED_PROBE in marlin and then determine and set the Z Probe offsets.

comments.text:
I see that you tried to modify the fang to include a mount point for the mini IR. That didn't work? can you tell us why you switched to a side mount?
Thanks a lot the your design ;)
comments.author: bmarques

comments.text: Yeah, I had it running on my fan fang design but ended up running into a problem during a print where the ir sensor ran into the part and snapped the mount and damaged the sensor. The other issues with that approach was it wasn't height adjustable (I could have made it adjustable) and visibility of the nozzle was impeded by the sensor right in front.  Hence the design of this mount.
comments.author: bmarques

comments.text: Have you got it working ok? The blog says it needs to be close to the nozzle.
comments.author: KDog

comments.text: Yeah, it's working good for me so far.  The only issues I've had is the cable connector coming off the wiring because I used an ethernet cable to connect the board and occasionally if a part curls it can cause it to rub the sensor.  The offset from nozzle in the firmware for me was x = -43, y=2,z=-1.5.
comments.author: KDog

comments.text: Hi,
comments.author: jneilliii

comments.text: That is exactly correct.  I pulled the 5V from the icsc pins, see recently uploaded image on thing.  So connections are VCC to 5V, GND to Z end stop ground pin and OUT to the other Z end stop pin. In firmware enable FIX_MOUNTED_PROBE and then determine and set the probe offsets.

comments.text: Use these in place of the ones in the examples, make sure to adjust your sensor offsets for your machine. I chose to use the custom boot screen included in the examples folder of 1.1.6 and disable the default marlin boot screen.  Tried enabling both with all the other options the same and it was a couple of hundred bytes to big.

comments.text: UBL will never fit on the stock Creality board.  You have to use either LINEAR or BILINEAR.  I've tried both, and I think LINEAR works best. I have not yet tested 1.1.6, actually was about to look into that one today.

remixed_from.title: Rick's Portal Gun from Rick and Morty

title: Rick and Morty Portal Gun - With Universe C 137 display

description.text:
This is the exact same portal gun as 3DCentralVA's, except for two things:

  • The knob in 3D Central's files has a hole in it (non-manifold)- it's fixed in this version.
  • The screen isn't just red; it's a block with "C137" on it, and I used Prusa's ColorPrint to get
    the text red. If you don't want your portal gun set to that universe, you can play with the
    OnShape file I have here:

https://cad.onshape.com/documents/13f18fc7896e7e925be9e2db/w/a4c7d2cf1b7c5a4fc576fdc6/e/e4dcdbd5dcc7d776feb8074c

Other than that, it's the same gun. I printed mine out of white PLA, translusent green PETG,
and black and red ABS. Happy Printing.

title: CATAN Game of Thrones [add ons]
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This digital file includes:

-6 "GoT themed" player cities/settlements/roads. Each player has 4 matching cities and 5 different settlements.
-6 lumber tiles (Weirwood variant). Measuring 3 3/4" x 4" each. Straight edge or jigsaw options (straight is recommended).
-Felt cutout for Weirwood tile and pips
-1 robber (Greyjoy squid)
-2 awards. Longest road depicts Baelish sigil with 5 roads, Largest army depicts the Hound, Brienne of Tarth's sword, and the Mountain. (Options included for either using a single piece of wood or inlaying two different materials).

If you would like players and awards that look similar but are NOT GoT themed, here is a link: https://www.etsy.com/listing/540085532/catan-base-set-accessories-awards?ref=listing-shop-header-1

Game of Thrones themed files are accessories and cannot replace the official Catan game produced by Mayfair. A copy of said game will need to be purchased in order to have all pieces required for gameplay.

Official Mayfair Catan board game: http://www.catan.com/
HBO, Game of Thrones (Television series): http://www.gameofthrones.com
George R. R. Martin, Song of Ice and Fire (Book series)

If you are unsure of how many tiles you will need or would like general tutorials here is a helpful link: https://imgur.com/a/e1dZm

My digital files are mix-and-match to make your own custom set. All purchaseable digital files are available in my etsy shop, and any free files (including the default center tiles) are available through thingiverse here.

Etsy: https://www.etsy.com/shop/EttuArtem
Thingiverse: https://www.thingiverse.com/Carlotta4th/designs

author: Carlotta4th

print_settings.Resolution:: what you wish, mine was at 0.3mm

title: Cable Chain Enlarged with smoother action

description.text:
End mounts now available and added, for Geeetech prusa I3 pro (C) .

For my dual extruder printer the chain on thingiverse wasn't heigh enough for all of my cables. (also some mods made ti the printer :) ).
I also found that the lower round edge would not come out looking good without some support.
And the movement between the links was quite rough.
I've redesigned these links for an addition 5mm space in height (width is the same!).
And the rounded edge is now a 45 degree angle, no support required.
And it is still compatible with the original ;)
Also trimmed 0.05mm in width from the inner sides to give a much smoother motion!.

Now you don't have any issues while printing!.

Enjoy ! ;) now you can put all your cables in.

Derivate from the cable Chain by Modelstation

title: Drilling template for pipe clamps
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Here's a drilling template I made for the pipe clamps to fit over an 1.25 inch box section so you get the holes central and properly spaced. This is an after thought after assembling my antenna and realizing I'd inadvertently drilled one set of holes a fraction too far apart. I figured if I'd made one of these before I started rather than relying on my measuring and marking I wouldn't be reprinting a set of pipe clamps with the spacing of the holes adjusted to compensate for my error right now.

Drill out at 5mm with the template then widen the hole to suit if you're using rivnuts like me.

author: bshephard

description.text:
Here's a coffee mug of my "mug". So it's a mug mug? I'm not sure why anyone would want a coffee mug of my head (well except me) but if you want it, here it is! I printed it on a FormLabs 1 resin SLA printer with Porcelite resin which is a resin with Porcelain in it that can be fired into Porcelain and then glazed and fired again. There's a hole in my head! (see pic near the hair line) Yeah, actually there's probably more than one hole in my head, but I tried to patch the one for the model so it should be solid now. The Porcelite resin is pretty expensive but this liter was given to me by a friend so I thought it might be nice to make a custom coffee cup with the stuff and this is what I came up with. The Scanect software free version only allows so many polygons but it at least has a nice stylized low poly look.

I'll try to update when I get it fired and glazed and maybe a pic of me drinking from my "mug".

http://tethon3d.com/product/porcelain-ceramic-resin/

UPDATE:
I had the cup fired but it made a lot of smoky fumes and carbonized the insize of the kiln and the cup turned to dust and smallish chunks. I'm not sure what happened. I've sent an email to the company asking what may have happened. Bummer. I'll probably try again by printing one in plastic, then making a plaster mold from it, and then making a cup from ceramic slip and then firing that. That should work instead.

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Formlabs Form 1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

no

Post Printing

After printing, remove the supports and sand off the bumps from the supports. It will need to be fired to a bisque state, then glazed and fired again so that it can be food safe to drink from it.

Design

I designed this cup by first 3D scanning my head with an Xbox 360 Kinect scanner attached to my laptop with the Scanect software. I hollowed the model with MeshMixer. I added a handle with Tinkercad. I added supports and printed with PreForm. The resin type is Porcelite which is a resin with Porcelain in it that can be fired to be a real porcelain cup.

http://skanect.occipital.com/
https://www.tinkercad.com/
http://www.meshmixer.com/
https://formlabs.com/tools/preform/
http://tethon3d.com/product/porcelain-ceramic-resin/

title: Special Allen Wrench style Nut Holder

description.text:
I needed to change the Z Nut Lock on my MPCNC machine recently https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724999 . Holding that one locknut in place at the correct angle with a needle nose to get the threads started just was not working for me. I was determined not to have to take all those parts apart to change that & came up with a specialized allen wrench style nut holder. I just used the plastic part to hold the nut in place long enough to get the threads started, then was able to use my needle nose to finish tightening it.

This can be used with the thingiverse customizer or edit the openscad file on your machine.

You can also use this to create a plastic Allen Wrench
For the Allen wrench STL file I changed:
Allen_Curve_Rad = 6;
Add_Ht = 10;
Socket_ON = 0;

I printed this with 20% infill and a brim to get it more surface to hold it to the print bed.

description.text:
This is a case for the Brew Probe that was created on my youtube channel http://www.youtube.com/misperry. The device measures the temperature of homebrew while it is fermenting so that you can keep an eye on your fermentation temp. This transmits it over WiFi via MQTT protocol to a HomeAssistant system where you can access it through a webpage any where in the world.

Check out the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Heo8ZwFT4ig

title: Traxxas TRX4 ESC Power Button Remote Lever - Turn it on without taking the body off!

description.text:
This allows the ESC button to be actuated with the stock body shell still clipped on. Useful when you want to power on / off the truck without removing the body shell.

If you could see the LED on the ESC you could change modes too, but the body is pretty opaque. You could drill a hole large enough to see the light, however.

The bracket fits under the mounting arm for the rock slider on the left side and has a small hook that holds the other end of the bracket under the ESC platform. This allows a clean install without the need for a chemical bond (double sided tape) as a mechanical bond is must stronger and less likely to fail.

The only additional hardware required is a 3mm cap screw, the same that holds the rock sliders to the chassis. Most hobbyists will have several of these lying around.

Printer:

Prusa i3 mk2

Rafts:

No

Yes

comments.author: bshigenaka

description.text:
Press fit mount to attach an 80mm fan to a MakerGear M2 on the x-motor side of the gantry.  
I was having trouble finding decent 24V 50mm fans, and there were clearance issues with the front bed clip, so I decided to go to an 80mm fan and side mount it. This mount clamps on to the corner of the gantry, and the fan slides onto the prongs. I haven't put in anything to secure it there, but it doesn't seem necessary. (I haven't actually run the fan from that location as I am waiting on the proper connector). You can see in the photo of the outside face where I had to pause the print because the current 50mm fan got bent up from the bed clip.  
This can probably be adapted to mount other things in that location as well, such as a camera. Care should be taken so that anything being mounted does not interfere with the extruder at the end of its X travel.  
See instructions for testing the clamp fit before printing.  
UPDATE: the printed fan prongs were too fragile, so I've removed them and added holes for screws. Use 6-32 or 8-32 1 1/4" screws with nuts.  
UPDATE: I do not recommend this fan setup, I found it lacked cooling at the nozzle and went back to the stock fan setup. I leave up the files in case they turn out to be useful to anyone.

Print the associated clamp test first to make sure how much clearance to use for the clamp. It will print out four test clamps, sized from -0.1mm clearance up to +0.2mm clearance, from left to right. Try them on for size, then set the clamp_clearance variable accordingly. Mine press fit securely at 0.1.  
Print the mount itself flipped around 180, so that the prongs are facing up.

print_settings.Notes:: The single transparent bowl next to the red/orange/yellow stack was done with 3DK PLA Kristall filament. This is the best transparent filament ever. It sticks well on blue painters tape without heatbed, and the print had no problems at 215°C and 100mm/s, normal flow. With taulman t-glase, I had to start with 230°C and 30mm speed to make it stick at all. extra strands and knots formed on the bottom layers, when going above 110% flow. But for the single-pass wall, I had to increase flow to 150%  to make it nice and shiny.

title: Hex bowl container
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A hexagonal shaped container for small parts during assembly. Due to the shape and the rounded corners, it is easy to grab even the smallest parts with our fingers from that container.

42mm heigh, 90mm wide, so that a human hand can comfortly operate inside and outside the container.

Two versions of the container are uploaded as STL files. One with 1.5mm wall width, the other filled. Use the filled container with cura's 'spiralize outer contour' or 'hollow out' function to create containers with thinner walls.

I have done a number of single walled containers they work very well.

A friend needed a 45º corner wall mount. I could not find one so I designed it for him. I've included a mount for a straight wall. The insert can fit both mounts. Printing time for a corner mount and the insert together is roughly around 5 hours using 84% fill on the Afinia H480.

To mount in the wall, first drill appropriate size hole for nail or screw. Mark holes on the wall where mount is too be placed and the drill screw or hammer nail through the holes in mount and into the wall.

One can also use the "Command Strip" on the back of the mounts to avoid holes in the walls.
Be sure to use heavy type to bare the weight of not only the sensor but the cable as well.

NOTE: These designs is free to use at your own risk. Venturon's and it's designers are not responsible for damages or injuries caused to walls, sensors, or to persons involved.

title: OXO On Conical Burr Coffee Grinder Shield

description.text:
Nothing terribly fancy here. I bought this coffee grinder a while back and because the container sits a little ways below where the grounds are released, there is potential for loose grounds to miss the container. After a few grindings, it's pretty apparent and your counter top and grinder is likely in need of clean up.

I made this small funnel-like shield to try and help with this. A small lip keeps it in place right at the top of the container. It is wide enough to catch most, if not all, grounds that may try to escape while also shallow enough that it will the bottom of the grinder when you remove the container - no need to hold it during container removal or placement.

Supports shouldn't be needed, though you might get a smoother print inside with them and some minor post cleanup.

print_settings.Notes:: I printed in ABS and the print was flawless

description.text:
What up snitches, this is a mount designed primarily for the RunCam Split. when you get the cam you'll notice the mount it comes with, works.... in a perfect world. So when I recieved it and got all excited to install it I noticed that there was no way on gods green earth it was going to function. Sooo i searched on here and found a few mounts that all provided the same issue, the issue being i end up getting allot of the frame from the quad in the picture. This design i made is to fit the Butter kwad from impulse RC ( http://store.rotorriot.com/pre-built-butterkwad-alien-by-impulserc/ ). This design gives you a 30 degree angle that is what is mostly used for all these quads. I kid you not you print this with zero support and use the screws that are provided to you in the RunCam split, bolt the camera on and slide the frame over the quads support frame ( tolerance is high so slowly work the 3d frame evenly on the quads support and you'll notice an awesome fit) and you are done.

  1. It clears the frame
  2. the holes are designed at 30 degrees and they are pre installed.
  3. The frame works on the RunCam swift and Runcam mini :-)

description.text:
After having my inkjet printer in storage for a couple of years the continuous ink tubes developed air bubbles that I wanted to remove using the vacuum method. This little pump has enough volume to do the job in a single stroke.

The printed parts are a nozzle, plunger, rear guide, and a handle.

Other than the printed parts you will also need a couple of O rings (for the nozzle and plunger), some 6.35mm or 1/4" aluminium rod, and some DN20 PVC water pipe. I got all of these from Bunnings so should be easy enough for anyone to get.

Parts are glued together using quick set epoxy and before use a light spay of dry lube should help keep friction down.

print_settings.Notes:: Printing in ABS at without scaling up any might be a little sloppy, but it doesn't seem to matter much since the only thing it has to do is grab the knot and slip into the end of the aluminum pole.

title: Aluminum Pole Shock Cord Retainer Insert

description.text:
Tie a couple of knots in some shock cord (also commonly called bungee cord) and stuff the knotted end into the slot in the side of this thing. Then you have a little plug insert that will retain the cord inside the end of an aluminum pole like the ones commonly used on camping tents.

Since it's likely this would be used on tents, chairs, etc outdoors in the heat, or might be kept in a car, it would probably be best to print in ABS or something that can withstand higher temperatures.

This seemed to print best with the end-cap part on the print bed. I tried printing it sideways too, because I thought that might make it less likely to separate on layers, but the print was a little sloppy that way with the support material. Would be curious if anyone finds a way to print that's both neat and strong.

This should print roughly the size needed for a pole with an inside diameter of around 10mm. Scale it up for larger poles / and larger shock-cord diameter. Wouldn't recommend scaling down any unless you have a much more precision printer than me.

author: MJCHARON

description.text:
Here is an unusual space filling polyhedron described by Guy Inchbald in a 1996 Mathematical Gazette paper. Updates and more information are available at - http://www.steelpillow.com/polyhedra/five_sf/five.htm The polyhedron has 11 vertices and 11 faces and is described as a bisymmetric hendecahedra.

Six blocks were created from this polyhedron. One is the basic polyhedron. As the polyhedron has four different faces it was possible to make 4 different pairs of polyhedra each of which shares a different face. Finally a set of 4 polyhedra makes a unit, described at the web site, multiple copies of which pack to fill space.

OpenSCAD code is included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm

The blocks may not be appropiate for young children. To make printing multiple copies easier the blocks were kept small. They tend to be somewhat awkward to position; care must be taken.

An easy way to start is to make a base using a number of the 4 polyhedra blocks. With a base established blocks containing 2 polyhedra can be carefully added. Single blocks can be added using face planes approximately parallel to the xy plane. Color coding the blocks is helpful in understanding the packing.

Stacks of blocks always represent something extracted from the infinite 3-dimensional array of polyhedra. The basic polyhedron has 2 planes of symmetry. Stacks of blocks are perhaps more interesting if at least one plane of symmetry is preserved during construction. The images above serve as suggestions for experimentation.

author: Jonathan_K1906

print_settings.Notes:: See the summary for how to determine the optimal melt temperature of your particular filament.

title: Interlocking calibration clips - Curves and straights

description.text:
Interlocking calibration clips with curved and straight features for calibrating two filaments to each other. These clips work for calibrating multiple filaments on a single or dual extruder system. They can also be used to calibrate a single filament to itself.

If you are designing a multi-part assembly and need things to fit together these are the clips to use to determine the physical and thermal properties of your filaments.

The clips have a 0.2mm gap between straight parts and a 0.25mm gap on curved features. This allows for the 0.1mm tolerance that most printers and machining operations can hold to and results in a feature fit between parts with about 4 thousands of an inch clearance.

Testing of the clips is accomplished by printing the set found in the single STL file and flipping one of the clips upside down on top of the other to test the fit of the features. If the clips are loose then you are under extruding and need to lower the nominal diameter of the filament or increase the extrusion multiplier. If the clips are too tight then you are over extruding and need to increase the nominal diameter of the filament or decrease the extrusion multiplier. When the clips fit easily together with no wiggle and stay put you have precisely calibrated filament.

Note in the images that one filament calibrated with a nominal filament diameter of 1.66 and a melt temperature of 220 C while the other calibrated at 1.74 and a temperature of 215 C. Both of these are different than the physical measured diameters. Yet both filaments produce matching precision parts while being extruded from identically micro stepped extruders. This is the whole point of calibrating to the thermal properties of a filament.

The last two images show how to find the optimal melting temperature. By extruding out a constant stream of filament you should get a rope like coil with a vertical strand to the nozzle. It will stay this way when you stop the extrusion. I call them cobras because that is what they remind me of. If the filament is too cold it will pig tail and curl under the nozzle. Increase the temp 5 C. If the filament is too hot the vertical part will lean over and spider web as it sags when you stop the extrusion. Drop the temp 5 C. With a good melt temperature you have a +/- 5C range for adjustments to counter oozing (lower the temp) and perimeter gaps (increase the temp).

Printer:

ReliaBuild 3D

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

24%

Notes:

See the summary for how to determine the optimal melt temperature of your particular filament.

Test fitting

The first layers of the clips need to be opposite and to the outside of each other to avoid calibrating to the bed squish edge that is dependent on the tightness of the bed leveling.

description.text: Holder for Orange R615x r/c receiver. Holes spacing for Actobotics beam

Printer Brand:

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

medium

Notes:

Sliced with Simplify3D
Designed with Fusion360. A very small dab of hot glue used to hold receiver in just in case, but is pretty snug at baseline.

Note: Although this design has been greatly refined and should not require much adjustment, if you make this design and do wind up experiencing any issues, I would greatly appreciate feedback and/or a make to show me how it works for you.

This is an extension for bassoon that is inserted into the bell in order to play low A below the instrument's lowest note; B flat 1. This low A occurs often enough in music that most bassoonists can play it through the use of precise blowing techniques, or various types of low A "extensions" inserted into the bell.

Professional low A extensions exist but are often expensive.This model is a cheap, durable alternative that I have refined over several months of playing to ensure it has proper tuning. This is the third version of the design, and the culmination of nearly two years of refinement of the previous two designs.

With most non-professional extensions, the bassoon's low B is often rendered too unstable to play, but with this design it still mostly plays (but slightly sharp). The tone of the rest of the instrument is slightly affected but not too drastically above G2, and I can still play up to G5 regardless of the extension.

Important note: always print with the wide end/opening of the tube on the platform. This negates the need for rafts or supports.

Another Important Note: Do not scale down the print, even if it is too tall for your printer. The bunched up bit at the top can be clipped off after printing.

1: Print 2 of any one of the bassoon extension files but cancel the second print halfway through. This will leave you with one complete extension file and one section of tubing with the diameter of the wide end of the extension.

2: Wrap either painters tape or duct tape around the narrow end of the complete extension enough so it can be slid into and out of your bassoon's bell with ease but will not come out during normal playing.* See figure 1 for a visual example using duct tape. If equipment for steps 3 and 4 is not available, the extension can be used at this point. However, it will play slightly sharp and mess up the intonation of low B drastically.

3: Cut the incomplete tubing down so you have a section of pipe 35mm high the same diameter as the wide part of the complete extension.

4: Place the 35mm pipe against the wide end of the complete extension and secure the two together to create one long continuous pipe. This can be achieved using tape, or by melting the two together using a soldiering iron or hot tool. (See figure 2 for the soldiering iron method's results). When this is done, the extension will be usable and in tune. Varying how deep you slide the extension in the instrument also affects its tuning like with the bocal.

*The precise amount of tape/cork needed will vary between specific bassoons and with the thickness of the tape/cork used.

Figure 1: A demonstration of how to wrap duct tape around the narrow end Figure 2: How I welded the small section to the complete extension. Mine is a bit more beaten up to accomodate the G# extension which can fit inside it.

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/HZhLZ2U4EZo" ></iframe>
A sound test of the extension using my bassoon

description.text:
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/6gUXZMI59LK

The base and the roof are in PETG. The glass is clear PLA.

Twelve neopixel leds per lamppost. The first lamppost contains one ESP-07 and a DC/DC regulator (5V/3A). The ESP07 RX pins it connected to the neopixel in data and the neopixel out data is then connected to the next lamppost neopixel IN. On every third lamppost a DC/DC 5V converter is added to reduce the voltage drop. The Power supply could be 12V to 24V.

Source code for ESP-07 and example code in python is also given. Be aware that you need to specify the number of maximum leds because the code verifies the number of bytes to be received in the UDP packet.

This is a small video when you power up the lamppost.
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/s/zsd5hs7a7idw9di/VID_lamppost.mp4

Be sure that your wifi setup is done otherwise the LEDs won't lit. The ESP-07 is compiled with the WIFI manager then you need to connect to the ESP-07 wifi first and set your own wifi.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Only use supports for the base. 5 mm spacing support is good enough. Use a xacto knife to remove the support on the latches and an allan key to break the support inside the wire channels.

Be aware that the PLA window is flat on one side and it is the top. When you print it put the flat part on the bed surface by rotating the part 180 degree.

Blender enthusiasts, you can have fun playing with your own shapes if you want. Open the blender file and duplicate as many or as few as you like. You can make grooves in the side of the shape by deleting certain rows. You can also keep duplicating layers and moving them down. Use snap-to-grid to make it easier. description.text:
I odered a bunch of these 40x40x20 blower fans to use as cooling fans on my Tevo and I thought "just use them for everything!!"

Printed with PLA and no cooling fan (as it hadn't been printed yet). I'd probably knock one up in ABS though if you intend to print PLA and ABS long term.

Unscrew the standard 30x30 fan from the E3D shroud and screw this mount straight on!

Mount the centre fan first, the standoff's are for the right hand fan because it needs to be mounted arse about face to the other two.

No supports needed. A couple sneaky internal fillets and chamfers let the printer build up the internal ducting.

The air outlet is angled down towards the nozzle internally so dont stress about it not having a "nozzle".

Also, ignore the washers used to mount the fan in the photos, I have corrected the mistake in the STL to accomodate for the error in prototyping.

Jury is still out with how effective this is compared to other cooling fan designs, but so far i'm pretty happy with it!

Let me know what you think an upload a photo if you make one and like it!!!

author: rab1d78

description.text:
Here is an experimental bracket for a Eurorack modular synthesizer. It works nicely with my Parametric Eurorack Rail but there are enough variables to change that perhaps you can get it to work with some other rail system. By adjusting the "tiers" parameter, you may create a 3U or 6U bracket. Each tier has a parameter determining the angle of each tier relative to the base.

ATTENTION: This design is provided for experimental and fun purposes only and has not been rigorously tested. If you have any qualms whatsoever about mounting your expensive synthesizer hardware to a pile of cheap plastic, I advise that you do not use this.

Printing is fairly straightforward. I recommend a fairly dense print, as a heavier bracket will be more stable. The provided default values should produce a 6U bracket that just barely fits on a Prusa i3 MKii when rotated this way or that. Your mileage may vary.

print_settings.Notes:: Print upside down, and you don't need supports

description.text:
The most often problem tripod user faces - lost quick release plate.

Those of you who have access to 3D printer, can print one, there are some models on Thungiverse. Unfortunately, most of the time they are published as non-customizable STL files, and author's requirements might differ from yours. For example, plate sizes are not that standard. Or screws you use are not the same length as author's.

Design considerations:

  • single-slotted design to allow for camera positioning
  • internal of the panel is auto-computed based on screw properties and plate geometry
  • screw is of the most common photo screw type, and consists of a head, grip and threaded part. D-ring is optional
  • in order to prevent screw from falling out accidentally, instead of using a stopper washer I decided to make an "eye" at one end of the slot. You need some force to screw the screw through the plastic of the eye, but there is no chance it goes back by itself. No plugs, no washers needed.

Printer:

Monoprice Select Mini

Supports:

No

100%

Print upside down, and you don't need supports

description.text:
This is a custom designed filament spool bearing rack for the Monoprice Select Mini 3D V2 printer.
I designed it because I didn't like the loud clicking that the feeder motor made as it tried to rotate the spool against the stock metal rack. This design fits over the existing rack so no printer modification is required. It was designed for Monoprice brand filament spools. It will allow any 4.5 cm and up inner diameter spools to slide over it. The spool width is 7.7cm.

Uses 2 x Universal standard size 8x22x7w bearings:

https://www.newegg.com/Product/Product.aspx?Item=9SIABYB4R69069&nm_mc=TEMC-RMA-Approvel&cm_mmc=TEMC-RMA-Approvel-_-Content-_-text-_-

The print contains the main piece and 2 optional end caps if your bearings fit loosely. Mine did not require these as the bearings press fit after printing.

description.text:
Hello all.
The mounts are designed specific for a Anycubic Kossel Linear Plus with heatbed. I am not planning to do much ABS on this one, but am considering to add a fan under rhe bed and add some cork insulation between bed and electronics.
First printed www.thingiverse.com/thing:2478566 to hold a 24cm heatbed and glass plate in place. Also works without glass plate as it is a nice fitted design (thx Ex1!)
Then wanted to make the kossel more rigid and designed the bottom side mounts to fit just under the linear rails. In order to get the belt through I disassembled the upper wheel of the belt. All is a little tight so i first put the nuts in the foot profiles at the correct location, and had the vertical bolts and nuts in place. Slided all in place and hoped the nuts would not have moved.
What you nee extra for the side mounts? Patience, and 3 x 6 M4 t-nuts and bolts.
Next on the program is to make equivalent mounts for the top.
Happy printing.

title: Vertical Stand for MacbookPro 15" non-retina with monogram

description.text:
I wanted to make a vertical stand for a macbook pro 15" but wanted to make it the double stand way, instead of a single one in the middle to prevent tipping over.
Also wanted to customize it a bit for the user. The original code comes from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:174143 Changes
  • Shrunk down to thin version so that 2 stands support a single laptop
  • Adjusted measurements for 15" macbook pro, non retina
  • Extended the height at which the laptop rests so that the power cord that goes down toward the table does not cringe
  • Added text monogram on the side

Printed with PLA on a K8200/3DRag.
Print standing up, NOT sideways.

author: nicolasg

title: fooyabt -  fessyFOO's Yet Another Belt Tensioner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
fooyabt - fessyFOO's Yet Another Belt Tensioner

Belt Tensioner for Tronxy X1 and other that use the v-slot extruded aluminum rails.

have STL's in a few sizes specified by their range of travel: 10mm, 15mm, and 20mm. filenames vary by rNN where NN is the range of travel. the nut is the same for all of them.

15mm one is probably sufficient. I like the 10mm because I wanted things as small as possible.

the puller and the case are designed to be printed upside down, no supports the stl files should be that way already.

caveat emptor: using this on the y axis of the tronxy x1, it still has a 4mm flange. which keeps the bed from getting all the way to the edge. if you were using that 4mm you will miss them. at some point I hope to redesign the part to handle that. (adding slot for the wheel, assuming it still has enough support. )

see youtube video for demonstration.

openscad source is available on github

Printer:

Tronxy X1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

after printing smooth out any rough bits. then test fit all the bits. thread the nut up and down until it runs smooth. the channels in the puller are designed to be tight so make sure to slide the puller in and out of the case. if/when it gets stuck use the nut to pull it back out. move it around till it moves freely.

last, the fit for the v-slot extrusion is set very tight. it may not feel like it fits at first. I suggest test fitting it on an open beam somewhere. (take the handle off the Tronxy X1, use top of Z axis. ) Note it's possible to tighten the pulley up too tight, pinching the arms together. If this happens you also won't be able to fit the feet into the v-slot.
a lot of trial and error. ... and openscad

remixed_from.title: TEVO Tarantula Modular Magnetic X Carrier with BLTouch

title: Mini V Wheel Magnetic Carriage with BLTouch Mount

description.text:
This is a remix of Banholdm's Magnetic X carriage and derollmann's TEVO Tarantual Modular Magnetic X Carrier with BLTouch. I also modified the carriage to fit with openbuilds' mini v-wheels and included the modified hotend mount and clamp for a hexagon hotend. The four extra holes I used to place screws through to anchor the belts for a corexy setup on my modified cobblebot printer. My BLTouch has yet to arrive, so I was unable to test this part with it on. I will update as soon as it comes in, but I don't see there being a problem attaching it to this part once it does. The model was modified in Sketchup, and consequently my slicer doesn't recognize it as manifold. However, it printed without a problem for me. If someone would like to repair the file, I would be happy to update the post.

Edit: My BLTouch came in today and looks to fit well on the hotend carriage. I have set my z-offset to -1.8 mm when mounting to BLTouch directly underneath the plate.

author: Tyler115

print_settings.Notes:: I printed the Clamp, Brace, and Slot Insert in PTEG with four shells and 50% infill. The Knob I printed in ABS with typical 30% settings.

description.text:
This set is based on Reversible Hold-Down for T-Slot Tables by WorksBySolo.

I added curved faces on the underside of the holddown clamp in order to better distribute the clamping force. I also added a low profile brace as well as an insert piece to ride in the slot, and a knob to hold it all together.

The Knob and the Slot Insert both have M5 nut traps that print upside down. In those cases I add a thin layer over the screw hole which must be removed with a drill or other sharp tool. This causes the top (bottom?) of the nut trap to print as a bridge rather than an overhang and results in a cleaner print.

You will need a M5 x 70mm hex head screw for each Clamp and an M5 x 25mm hex head screw for each Brace. The screws however each press into a Slot Insert piece and then point upward when in use. On the top of the Knob you should press a nut into the recessed nut trap after drilling out the extra plastic thin layer. For me it helps to have the nut threaded onto a long screw while I do that in order to make sure it is straight.

The nut traps are a bit snug intentionally, I heated the nut and/or bolt for about 15 seconds with a butane lighter and they slide into place easily. As an optional bonus I also used heat and pressure to press a washer into the bottom of the Knob. However after doing that I had to drill out the hole in the knob using a 5mm drill. I ran the drill motor in reverse so as to not damage the nut which was already in place. It also helps to use a tap on the trapped nut to clean the threads of any excess plastic.

Printer:

DaVinci FrankenPrinter

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

2mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I printed the Clamp, Brace, and Slot Insert in PTEG with four shells and 50% infill. The Knob I printed in ABS with typical 30% settings.

So after looking for a solution I didn't find anything to hold the cable near the end of the heatbed so it don't went over the printing surface when the Y axis is all the way back. So I end up taking the Holder of Nnivo (thanks for leaving the source file! :D!) and edited so it match my need.

Now i have the cable under control and is way more silent that any cable chain.

author: bbbue

title: WIP Aaron style cam mount. Runcam split.

description.text:
No not print 20170915 My buddy made a beautiful print of this for me and I made it wrong lol. the camera void is rotated 90 from what it should be. You can print this and it will work, but it will take a file and moving plastic around with a hot piece of metal. After that it does not align the camera and you have to eyeball it so half the purpose of the print is lost.

this is a work Progress. As of sept2 I do not recommend printing it do to the wide angle of the splits HD field of view. . its based on the hc44 mount Aaron did but its thicker for my larger airfoil. I included the black nose so that someone else might be able to use tinkercad to get what they need. This is made for a runcam split using the RC25G gopro lens option. Any gopro 2.5mm lens should fit the same. It will not work with the standard short lens. it should allow mounting of the cam at a max of 3 deg down tilt. You'd have to use something to hold the camera like that since it wont be friction fit, but you can do it if needed. It will probably go 4 degrees maxed out but its hollowed out for 0-3 deg mounting options.

All files needed for tweeking are included for download or you can use them here:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9n3Wh6GQ7HE/editv2

author: troyboy162
