Enjoy.

title: Filament Bearing Sleeve - Standalone -or- Companion to YAFSH
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I designed this as a companion to my YAFSH (Yet Another Filament Spool Holder) but it will also work as a standalone for your own filament holder. It was designed specifically with the MakerGeeks reels, but as it is, it will work with any spool that is 67mm thick with a 57mm inner diameter opening.

There are two versions. The original version utilizes the bearingSleeve-center and two of the bearingSleeve-endcap_x2 models. You can size the outer diameter of the center piece to fit your particular reel if necessary. The second version utilizes two of the bearingSleeve-standalone_x2 models only. You will have to resize the inner circle if your reel is a different size.

In my mind, the draw of the first version is that there is inner support for the reel as well as a central object against which you can snug the nut without the risk of deforming the reel. It's also simpler to resize the first version for various reels than the second, in my opinion. The choice of which to use is, of course, yours.

In addition the printed pieces, you will also need the following hardware:

  • 12mm-1.75 x 140mm bolt
  • 12mm-1.75 nut
  • 12mm x 26mm washer x2
  • Toro 110513 (Stens 215-211) bearing x2 (other cross-reference numbers can be found here)

I chose the components because, as a mechanic, this is what I had available in my shop this weekend. The bearings are 0.75" inside diameter; 1.38" outside diameter; 0.495" height. This particular bearing, however, also has two non-standard features which made it the perfect fit for this project - 1) there is a small (1mm) lip on one side and 2) there is a small (2mm) lip on the outer edge. Standard bearings without these lips will NOT work with this design!

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Make sure that the bearings are pressed into the endcaps with the lip facing TOWARDS the printed piece. the parts are assembled in this order - bolt; washer; bearing/endcap assembly (bearing facing OUT); center; filament spool; bearing/endcap assembly (bearing facing OUT); washer; nut. When used with my YAFSH, the lips on the bearings rest on the INSIDES of the uprights.

title: French Fridge Door Latch for Kids

description.text:
This is a latch that goes over most French door (opens from the middle of the fridge outward). Made to make it more tricky (albeit not impossible) for children always opening the fridge doors.

It's been designed to be a flexible print to allow for it to have some give and detach safely. The latch on the side helps for easily detaching one side - although if you are in a rush for a late night snack it will still give way with a bit more of a push.

Measurements in the how I designed section if you want to double check, and if anyone knows where Fusion 360 files save I can attach that on here too.

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

100% - not much to fill in anyway

Notes:

No supports needed, just make sure the flat surface to your printer is the side that has the middle attached. Because this is suited to TPU/Flexible prints, I tried to minimize the surface of thick parts attached to the bed - when I print this on a PEI surface it attaches more than strong enough. If you have this problem I recommend a two layer skirt to help with its removal as well

Making of a Latch

Lots of caliper measuring. I started making this in Openscad and after a day of "trying to get the right workflow" I bit the bullet and used this to learn Fusion 360.

Went well! the history and timeline editing made iterating and improving this design (the latch rectangle on the side, thickness of the cylinder hole and filleting edges for strength.

Outer diameter 89.20mm , inner part 48.95, diameter each circle is 20.30mm
// <---48.95--->
// o o <- 20.3
// <----89.20---->
//

Thank you mirror tool! The chamfered edge of the lower cylinders helps a lot with the printing while making a negible difference in strength. The addition of the filleting on the bar connectors helps prevent any sag.

title: ANET A8 squash ball damper foot

description.text:
ANET A8 is a noisy printer especialy when installed on an IKEA lack table that acts as a loudspeaker !

To avoid this, I've fastened my ANET over a thick, hollowed in the middle, medium density board.
Then to absorb some vibration I did four feet with two squash balls cut into two part and snapped into this thing. (use the soft balls marked with two dots)
You may either screw the ball support on the board or glue it with a double sided adhesive tape.

This is a flexible/universal mount that fits directly onto the stock stepper motor mounts. It is held in place by the top 2 stepper motor screws - the mounting face is 5mm thick, so you will need m3 bolts that are 5mm longer than the ones you currently use.

The top surface has 3x M5 holes that are spaced 10mm apart - these can be used for attaching additional mounts or aluminium angle to run your drag chain on.
The front and side faces have extra M3 holes for adding any other accessories you might want, or for securing cables with a cable tie (see photos). The front face also has an extra set of slots for a cable tie - I put this in as a 'might be useful' one day, there is no intended use as it stands.

description.text: This thing holds paper towel rolls in the most awesome way possible. There's other paper towel holders, but they suck. They have clips and levers and all kinds of lame stuff that will make your paper towels sad. This holder has a screw cap.. and paper towels really seem to respond to that. Screwing makes paper towels happy, and it's been proven that happy paper towels are 34% more effective.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50% or >

Notes:

Because the feet are printed vertically, be a little careful when screwing it down. If you torque it down too much, it may split. If it does, just unscrew it, superglue, and try again. The higher your infill, the less this is an issue.

The cap can be printed as low as 20% infill. Print it a different color for two-tone awesomeness and even more paper towel happiness/efficiency.

title: Bluey's House
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed this budgie play house to fit in a medium size birdhouse.

I printed the main House.stl at 0.3 mm, with multiple processes (20% in-fill 0-30% height, 5% in-fill 30-70% height, 20% in-fill 70-100% height), 60mm/sec with some custom supports. I printed the 2 parts for the sliding roof at 0.2 mm, with 10% in-fill to allow for light to pass through (I used Natural PLA for the roof). The design was scaled down to 90% of original for all 3 parts to fit my Wanhao i3 Plus print bed.

I used Earl's MulTFill filler on the outside walls followed by 400 grit (wet & dry) sandpaper and acrylic paint (5 coats) to give the play house more of a painted wood feel.

If you don't have a budgie this might also work well as a night light :) ...

title: Oculus Rift sensor mount for Ikea Expedit shelving unit

description.text:
I recently printed some nice Sensor wall mounts for my Oculus Rift CV1.

Then I got a third sensor to enable full 360 degree mode, but the optimal location for this sensor was not a wall, but the top of an Ikea Expedit (not Kallax) shelving unit.
So I figured I'd design this one to go with the existing two mounts - so I tried to stay true to the design style of the originals.

If anyone needs this for Kallax shelving units (the ones that replaced the Expedit line), just let me know how thick the shelves are, and I can easily adapt this one to fit.
(Or, well, basically any other kind of shelf, all I need is the thickness and I can adapt it).
The Expedit unit is 50mm thick by the way, just like this version of the mount.

There are two circular indentations inside the 'grip' area of the mount, these are meant for adding two anti-skid pads, to make sure the mount gets a nice and firm grip on the shelving unit, without damaging anything.
I used 10mm diameter pads, 3 mm thick. The indentations are 2.75 mm deep, making sure that 0.25 mm of the pad is exposed to grip the shelving unit. Works like a charm :-)

The top part of the mount is designed to make it possible to fasten the sensor using a 1/4 inch thumb screw, with a grip-base up to 20.5mm diameter. Total height of the screw should not be more than about 20 mm, or it will be difficult or impossible to get it in there.

Zortrax M200

I used a lot of the dimensions from the original mount, such as fillet diameters, body thickness and mount-hole diameters and lengths.

author: Gertsen

description.text:
I have designed a custom box cover for the Creality Ender-2 3D printer, using the MKS Gen-L V1.0 main board and the MKS TFT28 touchscreen controller.
The Fusion360 source is included for remixing purposes.

Assembly:

Mounting the main board on the base plate of the printer can be done using existing parts you disassembled from the stock printer. See the included photo's on the end.
All existing wiring can be used to connect the new board, except the original ON/OFF power button from the front face of the original cover, the new mainboard does not have an input for that. You should be able to connect the power button in between the 12V input, if you wish.

You can reuse the original 40x40mm case fan; mount it using the existing screws and add a fan guard if you want (print or buy).

Connecting the main board to your 12V power supply:

Depending on which power supply you received (or bought), you will need the following:

  • laptop brick style power supply: use two wires (must be of sufficient Gauge for 10A) or two metal pins and a female barrel connector; connect the Female barrel connector to the 12V power input terminal of the main board using either the wires or metal pins.
  • Meanwell style power supply: just two wires (must be of sufficient Gauge for 20A) to connect the 12V of the power supply to the 12V power input terminal of the main board.
  • before turning on the power, check for correct polarity of 12V and ground to avoid the magic smoke! ;)

Firmware included: Link to zip with firmware files

  • Custom Marlin V1.1.4 firmware to flash on the MKS Gen-L V1.0 main board; everything Marlin
  • Files for the MKS TFT28 touchscreen controller with customized boot screen and settings file (these must be placed in the root of a SD card to update the firmware on the controller); everything MKS

BOM:

  • MKS Gen-L V1.0 main board AliExpress link
  • MKS TFT28 touchscreen controller AliExpress link
  • 5pcs A4988 stepper driver module AliExpress link
  • most M3 parts needed for assembly can be reused from stock printer
  • extra 1pc M3 lock nut for the front catch hole
  • extra 10pcs M3 washers (8pcs for the screen, 2 pcs for the upper stand-offs)
  • extra 4pcs M3x12 for mounting the screen to the cover
  • some wiring for connecting to your power supply (depending on type, see above)
  • if needed: 2.1 x 5.5mm Female DC Power jack connector AliExpress link

description.text:
Changeover Cams for the Silver Reed Knitting Machine AW1 Weaving Arm.

Silver Reed machines were called several names depending on which country they were sold in. They were also knows as Studio, Singer, Empisal, and KnitMaster.

The AW1 Weaving Arm fits the SK326, 327, 328, 329, 560, 580, 260, 360 700, and 740 standard gauge (4.5mm) machines.
Supposedly you could also use the Weaving Arm on fine gauge machines with modifications. These Changeover Cams fit the standard gauge machines only.

With the AW1 Weaving Arm, you can weave a larger (chunky) yarn through the stitches of a standard gauge machine. Weaving can be accomplished with the standard presser foot of most machines, but requires manually moving the yarn from one side of the carriage to the other after each row. The AW1 Weaving Arm automates this task. Unfortunately most AW1 Weaving Arms are missing the Changeover Cams. The Changeover Cams are placed on either side of the knitted garment and trigger the cam lever on the AW1 arm. Without the Changeover Cams, you have to manually manipulate the cam lever on each row.

After many months of searching, I obtained a set of the original Changeover Cams for my AW1 Weaving Arm. From those original Changeover Cams I was able to measure and model up a 3D Printed replacement for the Cams.

Originally you were supplied two sets of the Cams, two for the left and two for the right. Normally only one Cam is used on each side of the garment, but it is recommended to place both cams on the bed together when knitting full bed garments to ensure the cam lever trips properly.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

I increased the number of outline/perimeter shells in S3D for this print to make the wedges on top of the cam more solid. I also printed at .1mm layer height to make everything as smooth as possible. I did make one set at .2mm and it seemed ok but on my flashforge at .1 was much nicer finish.

author: Godspeeeeed

description.text:
This is an attempt to make a 3D printed version of the 9 Gear Fidget Spinner. I'm sure the machined fidget spinner will spin better, but we want to print our own, right?

I offer 2 bearing options: 695 bearing (ID = 5mm, OD = 13mm, t = 4mm) or 1150ZZ (ID = 5mm, OD = 11mm, t = 4mm) bearing. I recommend the 695 bearing; the bearing used or the video is also 695. I have uploaded the files for the 1150ZZ version as well, since my first prototype was based on 1150ZZ.

Items to print:

  • 1x Center Gear
  • 8x Gear (Choose from 695 or 1150 version)
  • 1x Top Gear Frame (Choose from 695 or 1150 version)
  • 1x Bottom Gear Frame (Choose from 695 or 1150 version)
  • 1x Top End Cap
  • 1x Bottom End Cap

Items to Purchase:

  • 10x 695 bearing or 1150ZZ bearing
  • 4x 15mm M3 Flat Head Counter Sunk bolt
  • 1x 20mm M3 Flat Head Counter Sunk bolt
  • 5x M3 Nut

For assembly, refer to the assembly image or follow the assembly video at https://youtu.be/73aq4J0pjIE.

Update:
The 8 outer gears are compatible with my Planetary Gear Fidget Spinner. Any leftovers can be used here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2744194.

author: dionlevi

title: The BEST 2020 corners. Single and dual.

description.text:
Why another corner ...

I had trouble finding perfect 2020 corners. Some were not able to make the hammer nut lock properly to the frame, since the corner was in the way.

There is also a 3030 version:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2503636

Variants

  • Single corner
  • Dual corner with long skirt (covering the profiles)
  • Dual corner with short skirt (easier printing)

Features:

  • 5.2mm holes (for M5 screws, 10mm)
  • A 10mm gap for the screw cap to fall in
  • A 11mm gap on the extrusion side for the hammer nut to fall in and be able to rotate.
  • Two extensions on the extrusion sides to fall in the extrusion rail. (Nice and tight)
  • 6mm holes in the sides for additional mounting or cable-ties
  • The dual version is perfect for having it mounted on corners. Instead of two seperate corners you have one, which make sure they are perfectly aligned and the corner will be a lot more sturdy.

I'm using these for my HyperCube, and they are rock solid. I printed them with the following configuration:

  • Material: PETG
  • Wall lines: 6 (I don't want to have infill on the smaller walls)
  • Top and bottom layers: 4
  • Infill: 50%
  • Layer height: 0.3 (Lower is better, but this gives me already a powerful result)

More from this collection

2020 profile feet
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2503710

The BEST 3030 corners. Single and dual.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2503636

comments.text:
Great design! Thanks for sharing.
Any suggestions on how to position the long skirt corner on the printer bed?
Thanks again.
comments.author: MPeter

comments.text: Thanks, and no, I don't think you will be able to do without supports. I haven't tried that one yet. The one with the small skirt is the one I added in the pictures. The skirt has the same height als the nods which will secure in the extrusion profile, and thus is a bit easier to print with minimal support.

title: Moto G5 PLUS protective case - Rugged V1.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
A while ago I designed my first Moto G5 Plus case, which worked quite nicely with most materials. However, a few days after posting that design, I got a new, awesome looking matt PLA, which I immediately tested on the G5 Plus case. The material looked great and it printed like a charm, with zero warping. The only problem was the relatively bad layer adhesion, which made the case break when trying to squeeze the phone in.

To solve this issue and make this case printable in virtually any material, I decided to reinforce the cut-outs edges. Besides strengthening the case in the weakest points, it also adds more protection to the bottom area in case of a fall.

I have two cases in use for the past 3 months and they are still intact and perform greatly. The phone does not feel too bulky, it sits better in the hand and, most importantly, it is well protected. By the way....the green one is the one I use on a daily basis :D Also have a black one for rather serious occasions...or funerals:))

This package contains models with a 3D pattern on the back. It also includes a version without the "M" logo cutout, as some people might prefer a simpler look. For the "bulk" version of the case, which includes a .STP file to make it easier to customize, please take a look at this post:

-------------- BULK VERSION of this design will come SOON! --------------

The case is designed for the Motorola (Lenovo) Moto G5 Plus. It has two cutouts on the back, for the camera bump and for the Motorola logo, plus one small hole for the noise canceling microphone. On the side, it has a cutout for the volume key buttons and lock button and, on the bottom, it has a cutout for the charging port and the audio jack. If printed properly, it should snap nicely in, like a normal commercial case.

A really great advantage is that the phone sits much nicer in the hand and is not as slippery as without the case... so, with this one, you get both prevention and protection;)

Printer Brand:

Deltaprintr

Printer:

Deltaprintr Kit

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Preferably, print it with soft, flexible materials like ABS, PETG, TPU or BDP. However, some PLA seems to be OK as well, depending on how brittle it is.

If you material is warping strongly, try printing with a brim. If it is warping slightly, try to print the version with mouse ears ("_me" in the name). Cut them away with a cutter-knife after you remove the print from the build platform.

I designed it based on my personal measurements of the Moto G5 Plus and I would estimate an average measurement error of ca. 0.5 mm (on the corner fillets). Still, all the cutouts seem to allign perfectly and it clips really nicely around the phone.

The case is designed to be squeezed over the phone like regular, commercial cases.

The pattern on the back draws inspiration from 3D-illusion patterns. It has the effect of drawing the attention away from the, maybe, "imperfect" bottom layer... and it looks COOL!

Tevo Tarantula belt tensioner

I designed this tensioner for the Tevo Tarantula upgraded with Perry Posthoorn alu parts (https://taralu.net/collections/aluminium-parts).
The tensioner can be used on the X-axis (hotend carrier) and Y-axis (bed carrier). It will fit on the hotend carrier designed by Perry. It can also be used on the bed, but you will have to drill two 3mm holes in the aluminium bed carrier.
The tensioner consists of two printable parts, which can slide. Design tolerance was 0.3mm so both parts should slide inside another. If not, use a bit of sandpaper or tweak the step file a little in order for both parts to have the correct tolerances.
drill and tap the slider for M3 thread. Dril the other part, if necesary, so the screw turns well inside this parts. Picture should be self explanatory.

description.text:
This is a printable model of the Combine turret from Half Life 2.
I used the original model as a reference, but this model was made from scratch in Blender.

Designed with ease-of-printing in mind, there is one flat surface on every part, so that you don't have to use shitloads of support or a raft. The parts are already rotated to the best printing position.

Instructions:

  • Print with support enabled
  • Make sure everything fits together
  • Add Superglue to the holes and put it together
  • Shoot at Freeman
  • Fall over and panic!

The gun can swivel up and down if you don't glue it, the body and legs are meant to be glued.

The 4 holes on the gun are there to insert some small pieces of wire to match the look of the original, as there were wires coming out the back in a loop.

The combine turret design, that i used as a reference for this, as well as the HL2 logo i used in the preview image belong to Valve.

description.text:
I created this dust filter for the fan under the replicator 1 for cooling the electronics but it can be mounted on any 40mm fan directly or otherwise for any application. I moved the fan so it was flush agents the inside and dremeled a 40mm hole on the side for the intake. I then built this filter which covered it on the outside.
The 4 screw holes match that of a 40mm fan. Adding filters to intake fans are a good idea and will reduce or eliminate the need for you to clean your fans, heat sinks or electronics from dust, hair, and fur.
Dimentions: 40mm x 40mm x 11.5mm

• Print 1 of each part.
    • My print settings:
      Layer Height: 0.20 mm
      Infill: 13%
      number of shells: 2
      Extruding speed: 70mm/s
  • Cut and snap material between the 2 frame parts.
    • I used some sort of vacuum air filter you can also used mosquito net folded onto itself 2 or 3 times.
    • place the frame insert over the material and use it as a guide for cutting
    • place material into the frame body, then press/snap the frame insert over the material. some extra force may be necessary on the corners
  • Screw filter housing onto fan or service where you want to mount
    • you can use your fans existing screws if long enough, or slightly longer M3 screws.
  • Insert filter frame
  • clean/replace filter as needed
    If you are doing what I did and wish to improve your replicators electronics cooling fan do the following:
    Disclaimer: The following steps requires that you cut/drill in to the replicators right side wood panel. Do so with care, and I'm not responsible for any damages.
  • tilt printer backwards so it lays on the back side after removing the spool holders and unplugging it.
  • unscrew and remove bottom electronics wood cover (one screw on the lower center of the right wood panel)
  • clean out any dust/hair if any.
  • unscrew and detach the fan from the electronics and line it up on the outside with the screw holes (using the screws helps)
    • Use a pencil to trace the diameter of the fan, should be about 36mm in diameter and mark the 2 upper screws if you wish to use those.
  • remove the fan
  • use a dermal to carefully cut the 36mm diameter hole for the fan intake.
  • mount the filter housing on the outside and the fan flush agents the wood on the inside.
  • the existing screw threads should go back far enough to use, if not cut the spacers in half or use some washers.
  • reassemble everything and place the filter frame with material, in the filter housing.
